title: 112_hr1241
content: The Act is titled the "Rio Grande del Norte National Conservation Area Establishment Act" and includes definitions. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms related to the Rio Grande del Norte National Conservation Area, including Conservation Area, land grant community, management plan, map, Secretary, and State. The Rio Grande del Norte National Conservation Area is established in Taos and Rio Arriba counties, covering approximately 235,980 acres of public land. The purposes are to conserve and protect cultural, traditional, archaeological, natural, ecological, geological, historical, wildlife, educational, recreational, and scenic resources. The Secretary will manage the area to enhance its resources in accordance with specified guidelines. The Secretary will allow uses of the Conservation Area that further specified purposes, with motorized vehicle use permitted only on designated roads, except for administrative or emergency needs. The Conservation Area allows motorized vehicle use only on designated roads, with no new roads to be built unless necessary for public safety or natural resource protection. Grazing is permitted within the area, subject to applicable laws and regulations, and consistent with the area's purposes. The Conservation Area allows motorized vehicle use only on designated roads, with no new roads to be built unless necessary for public safety or natural resource protection. Grazing is permitted within the area, subject to applicable laws and regulations, and consistent with the area's purposes. Additionally, traditional collection of firewood, medicinal plants, herbs, and pinon nuts for noncommercial personal use is allowed in accordance with laws and terms set by the Secretary. Upgrading of existing utility right-of-ways through the Conservation Area is also permitted as long as it minimizes harm to the area's purposes. The Conservation Area, as outlined in subsection (b), must comply with the National Environmental Policy Act and other relevant laws, with terms and conditions set by the Secretary. The Secretary, in consultation with Indian tribes or pueblos, must protect religious and cultural sites in the area and provide access to these sites. The Conservation Area, outlined in subsection (b), must comply with relevant laws and terms set by the Secretary. Access to sites by Indian tribes or pueblos for traditional cultural uses is allowed, and temporary closures can be requested to protect specific areas under the American Indian Religious Freedom Act. The Secretary must develop a management plan for the Conservation Area within 3 years, which may include the Rio Grande Corridor Management Plan. Consultation with state and local governments, tribal entities, land grant communities, and the public is required. The Secretary must consider recommendations from Indian tribes and pueblos for ensuring access to religious and cultural sites, enhancing privacy for traditional activities, and protecting cultural sites in the Conservation Area. Acquired land within the boundary of the Conservation Area becomes part of it and must be managed according to the Act. The Conservation Area must be managed in accordance with this Act and any other applicable laws. The establishment of the Conservation Area will not change the management status of areas designated as part of the National Wild and Scenic Rivers System or managed as areas of critical environmental concern. In case of a conflict between laws, the more restrictive provision will control. SEC. 4. DESIGNATION OF WILDERNESS AREAS. Designated wilderness areas in the Conservation Area include Cerro del Yuta Wilderness in Taos County, New Mexico (13,420 acres) and Rio San Antonio Wilderness in Rio Arriba County, New Mexico (8,000 acres). These areas are managed in accordance with the Wilderness Act. The wilderness areas designated in the Conservation Area are to be administered according to the Wilderness Act and this Act. Any land acquired within these areas becomes part of the wilderness area and is managed in accordance with the Wilderness Act. Grazing of livestock in designated wilderness areas must adhere to specific guidelines outlined in the Wilderness Act and other applicable laws. Buffer zones are not created around wilderness areas, and activities outside these areas are not restricted by this section. The release of Wilderness Study Areas outside designated wilderness areas shall not be restricted by this section, as they have been adequately studied for wilderness designation and shall be managed in accordance with the Act. SEC. 5. GENERAL PROVISIONS. The Secretary must file maps and legal descriptions of the Conservation Area and designated wilderness areas with relevant committees, with the same legal force as if included in the Act, allowing for corrections. The information will be publicly available for inspection. The Conservation Area and wilderness areas designated by section 4(a) will be part of the National Landscape Conservation System. The State retains jurisdiction over fish and wildlife on public land, but the Secretary can designate hunting restrictions for safety or public use. Federal land within the designated areas is subject to withdrawals, with exceptions for valid existing rights. Section 4(a) of the Act withdraws land from public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws. The Act does not affect treaty rights.
